title: 113_hr3616
content: The "Protecting Seniors from Health Care Fraud Act of 2013" aims to educate seniors on health care scams due to their vulnerability to fraud. Congress recognizes the need for more information to prevent health care fraud among seniors. The Social Security Act is amended to include a new subsection on distributing information about health care fraud targeting seniors. Annual reports on these schemes and steps taken to combat them will be provided to Congress and the public. The Social Security Act is amended to include a new subsection on distributing information about health care fraud targeting seniors. Annual reports will identify prevalent fraud schemes and actions taken to protect seniors. Actions taken by seniors, law enforcement, and government agencies to combat health care fraud schemes and protect seniors. Policy suggestions to improve protections for seniors and assess the effectiveness of information provided in protecting them against fraud. The Secretary may omit information from annual reports on fraud schemes. The Secretary may omit information from annual reports on fraud schemes targeting seniors to protect ongoing investigations and prevent educating criminals. A private-public partnership between the Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Attorney General may be established to address fraud schemes. The Secretary may collaborate with public and private partners to develop a report identifying the top 10 health care fraud schemes, updated quarterly in English and Spanish. The reports will be disseminated by the Secretary. The Secretary collaborates with partners to develop quarterly reports on the top 10 health care fraud schemes, disseminated to Medicare beneficiaries. The reports are distributed through mechanisms reaching the most beneficiaries, including mailing a list of the top 10 schemes and including updates in quarterly Medicare summary notices. Additionally, the reports and updates are posted on websites. The annual reports and updates for the Health Care Fraud and Abuse Control Program are posted on various websites, including those related to Medicare, the State Health Insurance Assistance Program, and Senior Medicare Patrol. Information for the reports is gathered from sources within the Department of Health and Human Services, including Medicare hotlines. The Office of the Inspector General and Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services have established hotlines and websites to combat Medicare fraud. Other resources include State Health Insurance Assistance Programs, the Administration on Community Living, and Medicare administrative contractors. The entities involved in combating fraud and abuse under the Medicare program include Medicare administrative contractors, the Indian Health Service, the Department of Justice (including the FBI), the Social Security Administration, and the Federal Trade Commission. Optional additional sources may include state agencies dealing with elder abuse and other governmental entities. The curr_chunk states that other governmental and nongovernmental entities with expertise in protecting seniors from healthcare fraud may be involved in combating abuse.
